meta_title: Warhol in black, Bowie in the nude: Victor Skrebneski shoots the stars – in pictures | Art and design | The Guardian
text_raw:

Photograph: Victor Skrebneski Warhol in black, Bowie in the nude: Victor Skrebneski shoots the stars in pictures Share on Facebook Share on Twitter Share via Email The American fashion photographer, who died last month aged 90, was known for his stylised black-and white-portraits of celebrities.
Here are some of his most striking shots All photographs: Victor Skrebneski Main image: David Bowie, pictured in 1991.
Photograph: Victor Skrebneski Wed 13 May 2020 07.00 BST Vanessa Redgrave, photographed in Hollywood on the set of the 1967 film Camelot.
First published in American Vogue, 1967 Facebook Twitter Pinterest Model Karen Graham pictured in her makeup room with her hair stylist Suga, advertising executive Alvin Chereskin and Victor Skrebneski in New York in 1977 Facebook Twitter Pinterest Diana Ross, photographed for the back cover of her album Baby It’s Me, in Chicago in 1977 Facebook Twitter Pinterest As well as providing artwork for the album, Skrebneski’s images were used to promote Ross’s film Mahogany, in which she starred as struggling fashion design student Photograph: Victor Skrebneski/Michael Ochs Archives/Getty Images Facebook Twitter Pinterest Andy Warhol, photographed in black turtleneck look that would become signature of Victor Skrebneski’s portraits.
As the last person to be photographed that day, Warhol was tired, which is why his eyes are closed.
Photographed at the Factory, New York, in 1972 Facebook Twitter Pinterest David Bowie, shot as part of his and Iman’s wedding photographs in Chicago in 1991.
‘He absolutely loved being naked,’ Skrebneski says.
‘He told me he didn’t know what he looked like.
